titleStmt.title: On the old Thorn cut down at Market-
-hill, the Seat of Sr Arthur Acheson
Bart 08.······Writ Sept. 14. 1728.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: At Market-hill, as well appears
By Chronicle of antient date,
There stood for many a hundred years
A Spatious Thorn before the gate.Hither came ev'ry Village mayd,
And on the boughs her Garland hung,
And, here beneath the spreading shade,
Secure from Satyrs sat & sung.Sr Archibald, that val'rous Knight,
Then Lord of all the fruitfull plain,
Would come to listen wth delight,
For he was fond of Rural Strain.(Sir Archibald, who's fav'rite name
Shall stand for ages on record.
By Scottish Bards of highest fame,
Wise 1Drummond, a famous Scotch Poet. Hawthounden & Sterling's Lord.But Time, wth iron teeth I ween,
Had canker'd all its branches round,
No fruit or blossom to be seen,
It's head reclining tow'rds the ground.This aged, sickly, Sapless Thorn,
Which must, alas! no longer stand,
Behold the cruel Dean in scorn,
Cuts down wth Sacrilegious hand.Dame Nature when she saw the blow,
Astonish'd, gave a dreadfull Shreek,
And Mother Tellus trimbled so,
She scarce recover'd in a week.The Sylvan Pow'rs with fear perplex'd,
In prudence and compassion sent
(For none could tell who's turn was next)
Sad omens of the dire event.The Magpy lighting on the stock,
Stood chatt'ring with incessant din,
And with her beak gave many a knock
To rowse and warn the Nymph within.The Owl foresaw in pensive mood
The ruine of her antient Seat,
And fled in haste, with all her brood,
To seek, a more secure retreat.Last, trotted forth a gentle Swine
To ease her itch against the stump,
And dismally was heard to whine,
All as she scrub'd her measly rump.The Nymph who dwells in ev'ry tree
(If all be true that Poets chant)
Condemn'd by Fate's Supreme decree,
Must dye wth her expireing plant.Thus when the gentle Spina found
The Thorn committed to her care,
Receive its last and deadly wound,
She fled and vanish'd into air.But from the root a dismal groan
First issuing struck the murde'rer's ears,
And in a shrill revengefull tone
This Prophesy he trembling hears.Thou cheif contriver of my fall,
Relentless Dean, to mischeif born,
My kindred oft thy hide shall gall,
Thy Gown and Cassock oft be torn.And thy confed'rate Dame who brags
That she condemn'd me to the fire,
Shall rent her petticoat to rags,
And wound her legs wth ev'ry bryer.Nor Thou, Lord Arthur, shalt escape:
To Thee I often call'd in vain,
Against that Assassin in Crape,
Yet Thou couldst tamely see me slain.Nor when I felt the deadly blow,
Or chid the Dean, or pinch'd thy Spouse:
Since you could see me treated so,
An old Retainer to your house.May that fell Dean, by who's command
Was form'd this Machiavilian Plot,
Not leave a Thistle on Thy land,
Then, who will own Thee for a Scot?Pigs and Fanaticks, cows and Teagues
Through all thy Empire, I foresee
To tear thy hedges join in leagues,
Sworn to revenge my Thorn and me.And Thou, the Wretch ordain'd by Fate
Neal Gahagan, Hybernian clown,
With hatchet blunter than thy pate
To hack my hallow'd timber down.When Thou, suspended high in air,
Dy'st on a more ignoble Tree
(For Thou shalt steal thy Landlord's Mare)
Then, Bloody Caytif, think on me.848-409P
